Rally To DefendPoliticalFreedom
The Political Rights Defense Fund, which is handling the
legal and fundraising aspects of cases filed against the government by the Socialist Workers Party (SWP) and the Young
Socialist Alliance (YSA), will sponsor a "Rally to Defend Political
Freedom" Sunday, Dec. 6 at 7:30 p.m. The rally will take place
at St. John's United Methodist Church, located at the corner of
27th and St. Paul streets. There will be a buffet preceding the
rally at 6 p.m.
One of the purposes of this rally is a protest against government campaigns which allegedly harass those who speak out
against the government's treatment of people who work, including black activists, unionists and socialists. The PRDF also plans
to gain support for the SWP and the YSA's lawsuit for a permanent injunction restricting the FBI, the CIA, the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, and other government agencies from
spying on the SWP and YSA.
Also, support is sought for the SWP's $10 million suit against
Associated Press and the New York Police Department for libel.
When a Brinks armored car was held up Oct. 20, an AP story
appeared on the front page of newspapers'across the country,
saying that one of the persons captured and arrested for the
robbery, Judith Clark, was a member of the SWA. "That,"
remarked Yvonne Hayes, a member of the PRDR "is simply not
true!"
The PRDF also hopes to build support for Mojgen HaririVijeh. Hariri-Vijeh is an Iranian student at Morgan State University who is threatened with deportation by the Immigration and
Naturalization Service. The INS says she failed to renew her
student visa, but groups like the PRDF allege that the INSA is
discriminating against her because of her socialist political beliefs.

Are They Really Listening?
First: Congratulations to all parties.
involved for arriving at what seems to be
not only a fair compromise, but ultimately
the best way of instituting plus/minus
grading. Having the new system take effect
starting with next year's freshmen should
eliminate the potential for contradiction in
and subsequent misreading of student
transcripts. The grade system itself, as
argued earlier here, will provide a more
accurate measure of performance at an
institution which is by nature competitive
and goal-oriented.
Special praise is due the Student
Council and its Education Committee for
so vigorously sounding student opinion of
the originally proposed across-the-board
implementation of plue/minus grading, and
for representing that opinion to the Academic Council. The Academic Council, in
turn, should be commended for being, in
the end, properly sensitive to student
wishes on this issue.
But: There is one aspect of this
happy conclusion which merits some
thought before it is tucked away and
forgotten, namely Dean Owen's statement
that "This decision shows that we listen to
the students." A proper response to that
statement is, "Well, yes and no." First of
all, "we" means different people in different situations. The faculty and the administration are by no means such a unified

entity that any student should make the
mistake of thinking of them as "we." Until
now, perceiving its unpopularity with the
students, administration members have
made a visible effort to disassociate themselves with the faculty on the matter of.
plus/minus grading, calling themselves
powerless in the matter.
More important, however, there are
other issues, as yet unresolved, where it is
by no means clear that students are being
listened to. The decision to ban rock music
from Spring Fair, though it was officially
made by the Student Council, was reached
long ago by the administration. The way in
which the ban has been rescinded represents a placating gesture more than anything else; it would be interesting to see
what would happen if the Student Council
voted to rescind the ban entirely. It is
doubtful whether the autonomy the SC
seemed to enjoy in enacting the ban would
still go unchallenged — the point being that
the administration wants no music at the
Fair, and that, for the most part, is how it's
going to be. No serious compromise —
such as the one presented by David Fishkin
(see story, page 1) — would be seriously
entertained by the administration.
So: This issue of plus/minus grading
has a happy ending, and let's keep our eyes
on the next one.

Dallas, Texas — More than a dozen doctors and nurses who either treated former President John F. Kennedy
during his final hours or participated in the autopsy of the slain president have recently stated that the official
autopsy photographs of the back of Kennedy's head do not show the same gunshot wounds which they saw and
reported to the Warren Commission in 1963-64.
The autopsy photos, which were among many items of evidence in the assassination kept secret by the Warren
Commission, were never officially shown to the Dallas medical witnesses during the various investigations into the
killing. After looking at them for the first time recently, however, nearly all of the nurses and doctors involved in
the shooting said that the pictures do not show the wounds as they actually were.
The testimony of these witnesses, which was assembled recently in a series of tape recorded interviews in
Dallas and several other cities, presents the most significant challenge to the official explanations of the assassination to date.
Among other things, the startling testimony indicates that members of the Warren Commission covered up
information about the 1963 murder; that there were three or more gunmen on the scene; that the president was
shot from in front, as well as from behind, in a well-planned ambush which was the result of a broad conspiracy.
"That's not the way I remember it," said Dr. Richard Dulany, a medical resident who was on duty in the
emergency room when Kennedy was brought in, later looking at a copy of an official autopsy photograph. According to Dr. Dulany, there is a "definite conflict" between the wounds as portrayed in the photo and the wounds
which he observed in the emergency room.
There were at least 22 witnesses in Dallas who have described a "large hole in the back of the head." Dr.
Dulany insists that the photo does not show the large, gaping wound which had blown out the back of the president's head.
Dr. Paul Peters, professor and chairman of the Urology Department at the University of Texas Southwestern
Medical School at Parkland, also questions the accuracy of the disputed photograph. Dr. Peters told the Warren
Commission: "We saw the wound of entry in the throat and noted the large occipital wound." After seeing the
pictures, he said, "I don't think it's consistent with what I saw. There was a large hole in the back of the head
through which one could see the brain. But that hole does not appear in the photograph."
(The President's widow also described a severe wound at the back of the head to the Commission: "But from

statement is, "Well, yes and no." First of

now, perceiving its unpopularity with the
students, administration members have

powerless in the matter.
More important, however, there are
other issues, as yet unresolved, where it is
by no means clear that students are being
listened to. The decision to ban rock music

made by the Student Council, was reached

Dallas, Texas — More than a dozen doctors and nurses who either treated former President John F. Kennedy
during his final hours or participated in the autopsy of the slain president have recently stated that the official
autopsy photographs of the back of Kennedy's head do not show the same gunshot wounds which they saw and
reported to the Warren Commission in 1963-64.
The autopsy photos, which were among many items of evidence in the assassination kept secret by the Warren
Commission, were never officially shown to the Dallas medical witnesses during the various investigations into the
killing. After looking at them for the first time recently, however, nearly all of the nurses and doctors involved in
the shooting said that the pictures do not show the wounds as they actually were.
The testimony of these witnesses, which was assembled recently in a series of tape recorded interviews in
Dallas and several other cities, presents the most significant challenge to the official explanations of the assassination to date.
Among other things, the startling testimony indicates that members of the Warren Commission covered up
information about the 1963 murder; that there were three or more gunmen on the scene; that the president was
shot from in front, as well as from behind, in a well-planned ambush which was the result of a broad conspiracy.
"That's not the way I remember it," said Dr. Richard Dulany, a medical resident who was on duty in the
emergency room when Kennedy was brought in, later looking at a copy of an official autopsy photograph. According to Dr. Dulany, there is a "definite conflict" between the wounds as portrayed in the photo and the wounds
which he observed in the emergency room.
There were at least 22 witnesses in Dallas who have described a "large hole in the back of the head." Dr.
Dulany insists that the photo does not show the large, gaping wound which had blown out the back of the president's head.
Dr. Paul Peters, professor and chairman of the Urology Department at the University of Texas Southwestern
Medical School at Parkland, also questions the accuracy of the disputed photograph. Dr. Peters told the Warren
Commission: "We saw the wound of entry in the throat and noted the large occipital wound." After seeing the
pictures, he said, "I don't think it's consistent with what I saw. There was a large hole in the back of the head
through which one could see the brain. But that hole does not appear in the photograph."
(The President's widow also described a severe wound at the back of the head to the Commission: "But from
the back, you could see, you know, you were trying to hold his hair and his skull on..."
Doris Nelson, a Dallas nurse who was the supervisor of the emergency room when Kennedy was brought there,
